As there has not been any accidental chemical releases from our facility that has caused an offsite impact, we are not required to plan any changes to our program.



CERTIFICATIONS

Based on the criteria in 40 CFR 68.10, the distance to the specified endpoint for the worst-case accidental release scenario for all processes at our facility is less than the distance to the nearest public receptor.

Within the past five years, the process(es) has (have) had no accidental release that caused offsite impacts provided in the RMP rule (40 CFR 68.10(b)(1)).  No additional measures are necessary to prevent offsite impacts from accidental releases.  In the event of fire, explosion or a release of a regulated substance from the process(es), entry within the distance to the specified endpoints may pose a danger to public emergency responders.  Therefore, public emergency responders should not enter this area except as arranged with the emergency contact indicated in the RMP Plan. not had an off-site release of TDI or an on-site Reportable Quantity (RQ) release of TDI in the last 5 years.  Production began in late 2016.  One incident involving a release less than the RQ of 100 lbs of TDI occurred in the 4th quarter of 2021 and is detailed below.

The Employer, Bridgestone APM at the time, now Archem America, Inc. makes foam seats for vehicles, which involves a process reacting the components polyurethane and TDI in molds, known as tools. The demold point is when the formed foam seat and the mold tool are separated after the curing oven where the foam is formed. The Incident occurred during the overnight shift of November 15, 2021, to November 16, 2021. An equipment malfunction occurred in the pouring area, which resulted in a sticky, pancake-like substance in the tools (i.e., seat molds), which did not cure and needed to be cleaned out to continue production. The supervisor, against Company protocol, told the employees to begin the process of cleaning the tools using gloves and scrapers. After a short period of time, two employees did not feel well and went outside for fresh air.  The area was immediately cleared of all production employees and only Respondents HAZMAT team was in the area to clean the tools. After investigation, it was ultimately determined that the mixture had the correct amount of toluene 2,4 diisocyanate (TDI), but not enough polyurethane in it.

This was not a release to any environmental media.  The pouring malfunction was contained in the tool, and the total release was less than 100 lbs.

In the event that a significant spill does occur, we will conduct a formal incident investigation to identify and correct the root causes of each event.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Modeling was performed using the EPA recommended ALOHA (Area Locations Of Hazardous Atmospheres), version 5.4.7 air dispersion model to determine potential TDI emissions from the worst-case scenario spill.  The ALOHA model predicted the toxic end point for a catastrophic tote failure that does not go past the Bridgestone APM Plant property perimeter.


The release rate calculated by the ALOHA program was a value of 0.00293 lbs/min.  This release rate rounded to 0.16 lb/min in order to have a release rate that would not be printed as zero by RMP*eSubmit.  The evaporation duration calculated by ALOHA was 60 minutes.  The evaporation duration time was entered as 60 minutes as allowed by RMP*eSubmit.  The toxic endpoint calculated by ALOHA® was determined to be 0.1 miles and was entered in RMP*eSubmit as 0.01 miles.


GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

We maintain a number of programs to help prevent accidental releases and ensure safe operation.  The accident prevention programs in place include:

1.	TDI is received in stainless steel totes
2.	Employees (Material Handlers) that handle the unloading of TDI receive training on truck unloading and storage
3.	Internal checklists are used for every unloading event to help reduce the risk of an accidental release.
4.	Material Handlers are trained in forklift operation for the lifting of totes, transport and placement of the TDI in the chemical storage room.
5.	The chemical room has a 5.5 inch dike for secondary containment.

KEY OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS SCENARIOS

EPA's RMP Rule requires that information about the worst case scenario(s) for the facility be provided.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario:


Worst-Case Release Scenario(s) Evaluation - Regulated Toxic Chemicals

The following is a summary of the worst-case scenario developed for the Sanborn facility RMP.  The tote volume used was 350 gallons.

A tote rupture was assumed to be the worst-case scenario which would release the tote contents into the chemical storage room secondary containment area surrounding the tote.  The total area of the secondary containment measures 550 square feet with a depth of 5.5 inches. The liquid TDI would be contained in the secondary containment area.  The amount of TDI that would be emitted is equal to the volume of TDI in a single tote in the secondary containment surface area. The worst-case release scenario assumed that the surface area emissions of the contained TDI would first be released into the enclosed chemical room area before being released to the surrounding area.

Our Worst-case Release Scenario would be a catastrophic failure of a single 350 gallon tote.  This would involve the involuntary release of up to 350 gallons of TDI to the diked area located inside the chemical room of the facility.

The RMP regulations require determining if the toxic endpoint for the worst-case release scenario remains within the facility property boundary or if it goes offsite and possibly impacts public receptors.  The toxic endpoint for TDI listed in 40 CFR 68 Appendix A - Table Of Toxic Endpoints is 0.007 milligrams per Liter (mg/L) (1 ppm).  This airborne concentration is the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals can be exposed

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Our facility produces polyurethane foam seat pads and backs for the automotive industry using a variety of chemicals and processing operations.  In our processes, we use the following chemicals that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the event of a substance release:

TOXICS

Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI).  Our facility has multiple totes with a capacity of 350 gallons each that contain the TDI.  TDI is a main component of the chemical mixture used to formulate the foam seat pads.
